channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Doctors Without Borders Health Center in Yemen Is Said to Be Bombed
item.description: The site was struck at least twice overnight by warplanes belonging to the military coalition led by Saudi Arabia, forcing evacuations, the group said.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Beijing Calls U.S. Warship’s Route in South China Sea a ‘Provocation’
item.description: The statement came after a guided missile destroyer sailed by one of several artificial islands that China has built in the disputed Spratly Islands.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe Turns Down Confucius Peace Prize
item.description: A Zimbabwean news organization reported that Mr. Mugabe decided to reject the prize after learning that it had nothing to do with the Chinese government.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Death Toll From Earthquake in Afghanistan and Pakistan Tops 300
item.description: A complete picture of the damage in remote areas isolated by difficult terrain and an active insurgency could take days to emerge, officials said.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: A damaged house in Mingora, Pakistan, the main town of the Swat Valley, on Tuesday, a day after a deadly earthquake hit the area.

item.title: In Cuba, an Abundance of Love but a Lack of Babies
item.description: An aging population, a scarcity of jobs and a liberal abortion policy add to a demographic crisis in Cuba, where many say they cannot afford to have a child.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pregnant woman waiting outside a hospital in Havana. Cuba's low birthrate is a problem more common to rich, industrialized nations.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Chinese Economist Responds to Critics of His Proposal to Let Men Share a Wife
item.description: Xie Zuoshi says he doesn’t think the arrangement has much chance of actually becoming legal, but he defends his reasoning.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Parents gathered at a “marriage market” at the Temple of Heaven in Beijing to seek spouses for their children. Xie Zuoshi, an economics professor, supports more flexible marital arrangements to address the surplus of bachelors.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese State Planning Meets ‘Schoolhouse Rock!’ in New Video
item.description: A new video has brought the world’s biggest publicity machine to a new era: 1973.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Ai Weiwei Setting Up Lego Collection Points After Company Refuses His Order
item.description: The Chinese artist and dissident said that the Lego Group had rejected an order for several million Lego bricks that would have been used to create works for an exhibition titled “Andy Warhol | Ai Weiwei,” scheduled to open on Dec. 11 at the National Gallery of Victoria in Australia.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:description: Ai Weiwei at the unveiling of his sculpture "Forever" outside the Gherkin building in London on Sept. 16.

item.title: Letter From Washington: How Trump Has Upended the Story Line
item.description: Reflecting the populist drift of the far right of the Republican Party, Donald J. Trump has deftly played into the central fears of many voters.
item.dc:creator: ANAND GIRIDHARADAS

item.title: Bangladeshi Officials Say 4 Arrested in Killing of Italian Aid Worker Were Not With ISIS
item.description: The authorities dismissed claims that the Islamic State was behind a fatal shooting in Dhaka last month, saying the motive was to “keep the government under pressure.”
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Poachers’ Cyanide Kills 22 Elephants in Park
item.description: The Zimbabwe Parks and Wildlife Management Authority said poachers had gotten away with three ivory tusks.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Former Official Pleads Not Guilty in Corruption Case
item.description: The former national security adviser made the plea in connection with $423,000 in Nigerian and United States currency seized at his homes.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Unelected Chamber in Britain Delays Cameron’s Spending Cuts
item.description: The House of Lords voted to delay the latest round of spending cuts proposed by Prime Minister David Cameron, which involve decreasing a cash benefit for people in low-paying jobs.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II in the House of Lords for the opening of Parliament in May. The Lords voted Monday to delay a proposed reduction in benefits available to people in low-paying jobs.

item.title: Belgian Authorities See No Terror Link in Car Crash at Army Barracks
item.description: A masked man who rammed his car into an army commando barracks set off panic in southern Belgium, but the defense minister said there were no reason to believe that terrorism was involved.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: President Joko Widodo of Indonesia Joins Trans-Pacific Partnership
item.description: President Joko Widodo of Indonesia met with President Obama in Washington and said his country would eventually join the Trans-Pacific Partnership.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: President Joko Widodo of Indonesia, meeting with President Obama at the White House on Monday, said his country would join the Trans-Pacific Partnership.

item.title: Challenging Chinese Claims, U.S. Sends Warship Near Artificial Island Chain
item.description: The maneuver by the United States Navy is a direct challenge to China’s assertion that the artificial islands it has built in the South China Sea are a part of its territory.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.media:credit: Center for Strategic International Studies, via Digital Globe
item.media:description: A satellite image from March showed work on an emerging artificial island at Mischief Reef, part of the Spratly Islands in the South China Sea. China has been turning submerged reefs into islands to bolster its territorial claims.

item.title: Violence in Syria Spurs a Huge Surge in Civilian Flight
item.description: The escalation in fighting, along with Russian airstrikes, was fueling the kind of desperation that has propelled a growing number toward neighboring countries and to Europe.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM and MAHER SAMAAN
item.media:description: Displaced Syrians near an abandoned house in the province of Aleppo. Relief workers say they believe at least 50,000 people have been uprooted, mostly north of Homs and in areas around the city of Aleppo.

item.title: Facebook’s Internet for All Is a Tough Sell in India
item.description: Facebook’s rocky experience since it brought stripped-down Internet access to India shows that good intentions and technological savvy are not enough.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL
item.media:credit: Asmita Parelkar for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The Reliance connection is very patchy,” said Shoaib Khan at his perfume and cellphone shop in Mumbai, India. “I would really have to sell the customer on it.”

item.title: Josef Ackermann Sees His Role in Cyprus as a Chance to Give Back
item.description: Mr. Ackermann, the former chief of Deutsche Bank who is now chairman of the Bank of Cyprus, had a role in the events that nearly destroyed the island’s banking system in 2013.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bank of Cyprus A.T.M.s in Nicosia, the Cypriot capital. The bank and the island’s economy are so intertwined that if the bank revives, so will the country.

item.title: Venezuelan Prosecutor Says Opposition Leader’s Trial Was a Farce
item.description: In a video posted online, a prosecutor, Franklin Nieves, criticizes a trial in which he helped convict Leopoldo López, calling it a farce, and says he has left Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN and PATRICIA TORRES
